passages.text:
- Swedish 2Q GDP revised up 1.5% - pt to 1.9% saar
- August core inflation likely to correct lower
- Norway's LFS U-rate fell, as expected, sharply in July

This week saw mixed news amid debate over a potential Riksbank ease again in September. The minutes from the August meeting were slightly more dovish than the press conference and the statement, with members assessing economic activity to be weak. This could, in isolation, have warranted a cut already in August. While higher-than-expected inflation in June-July prevented such a move, the Board also assessed that the recent upturn was most likely temporary, driven by a few volatile items. If inflation were to correct lower in the coming months, members appeared open to ease again.

Given these comments, next week’s flash CPI report is of extra importance. We look for a 0.3%-pt drop in core inflation to 2.9%oya, with risk skewed to the downside (details in the data section). This would narrow the gap to the Riksbank’s forecast from 0.4%-pt to 0.2%-pt. Adjusting for the forecast errors in June-July and applying Riksbank’s m/m% forecast for August, our forecast is one-tenth below the Riksbank’s (Figure 1).
Figure 1: Sweden core inflation forecast

Coming back to the week’s news, 2Q GDP was revised up from 0.4% to 1-9% saar. The GDP data is notoriously prone to large revisions, and we had also flagged an elevated risk of a large upward revision. Despite the upgrade, GDP fell well short of the Riksbank’s forecast of 3.5% saar (the level is 0.6% below projections). The report was impacted by large swings in several items, including investment, inventories and trade. Household consumption rose 1.8% saar. While encouraging, this was also well below the Riksbank’s forecast (3.5%).
The more timely NIER survey showed the headline index edging up 1.7pts to 96.0 in August, consistent with sluggish growth at 0.6%q/q saar. Labour market indicators remained at

weak levels, while the biggest change in the survey was the retailers’ price index. This posted one of the largest drops on record. The index, which is closely followed by the Riksbank, moved down in line with its long-run average, historically consistent with inflation below 2%.

We expect next week’s PMI to rise, but similar to the NIER survey still indicate below-potential growth and disinflation ahead. We project the composite index to rebound 1.3pts to 51.6, equating to 0.5% saar GDP growth. This is below our 3Q GDP forecast of 1.5%q/q saar. The PMI has, however, recently under-estimated growth (and suffered from residual seasonality, which is a long-standing problem in the months of June-July).

One area not captured by the PMI is government consumption, which we expect to accelerate in 2H25 and into 2026. In 2026, fiscal policy will clearly be expansionary as the Finance Minister this week announced that the 2026 Budget will contain unfunded reforms worth SEK 80bn. This was SEK 20bn above our forecast and almost double the size projected by the NIER Institute. While the details are still missing, we have raised our 2026 GDP forecast 0.2%-pt to 2.2%oya. Some of the details should, as usual, be revealed in the coming weeks ahead of the full Budget release on September 22.

We published a note arguing that the recent spike in the LFS unemployment rate was not sending the correct signal about the labour market breaking, hence the elevated level for the unemployment rate in June should prove temporary. The July LFS data, which were subsequently published, support this analysis. In that data, the unemployment rate plummeted 1.0%-pt to 4.5% sa, entirely driven by the volatile labour force (-1.3%m/m sa). Only once has the unemployment rate ever fallen by as much in a month (during the pandemic).

The registered unemployment rate, which recently has experienced a statistical break, was unchanged at 2.1% sa in August, likewise reinforcing our view of resiliency. Next week will also be a quiet week in terms of data releases.
MonPurchasing managers' index (manufacturing)Sep 1% bal, sa8:30amMayJunJulTotal manufacturing53.551.854.2

Due to sampling issues, the PMI is often volatile in June-July and inconsistent with moves in the NIER survey. This has also been the case this year. Our forecast of a 0.9pts decline to 53.3 in August should partly be seen in this context. A move lower is, however, also in line with our "fair value model" (which among other things includes lagged values of the order-to-inventory ratio). On the other hand, the NIER Manufacturing Index (adjusted for methodology changes) points to upside risk.
Wed Sep 3Purchasing managers' index (services)% bal, saMayJunJulAug8:30amTotal services50.654.348.851.6

Like its manufacturing counterpart, the services PMI is, in our view, an unreliable indicator in the months of June- July. Volatility has once again been large this year. The July services PMI looked, on the surface, very concerning, but given the above- mentioned seasonality issues, we faded this move. Consequently, we also expect some payback in August. Moreover, a move higher is supported by various indicators. We expect the Composite Index to rebound 1.3pts to 51.6. According to our models, this level is consistent with GDP growth at \(0.5\%\) saar.

Thu Sep 4Consumer prices (flash)Nsa8:00amMayJunJulAugCPI (%m/m)0.10.50.2-0.5CPI (%oya)0.20.70.80.9CPIF (%m/m)0.10.50.3-0.4CPIF (%oya)2.32.83.03.1CPIF ex. energy (%m/m)0.20.70.2-0.5CPIF ex. energy (%oya)2.53.33.22.9

We expect core inflation to drop \(0.3\%\) - pt to \(2.9\%\) oya (Riksbank: \(2.71\%\) ), with risk skewed to the downside. The June- July reports have been heavily influenced by foreign travel and car rental—partly due to much stronger- than- usual monthly price gains, and partly because of basket effects (basket effects will fall from \(0.65\%\) - pt to \(0.54\%\) - pt in August). These items will be important again for the August CPI. In August last year, car rental prices fell \(16.2\%\) m/msa, but we think a fall of more than \(20\%\) this year is likely, in isolationshaving off \(\sim 0.2\%\) - pt of CPI. Package holidays and international flights should likewise fall sharply, together lowering CPI by \(\sim 0.35\%\) - pt. We expect food and non- alcoholic beverage prices to decline \(0.6\%\) m/msa, with risk skewed to the downside (among other things due to coffee prices). Higher electricity and fuel prices should contribute to headline CPIF increasing \(0.1\%\) - pt to \(3.1\%\) oya (Riksbank: \(2.7\%\) ).

Source: SCB, Swedbank, Silf, AMS and J.P. Morgan forecasts
